awd_titl_txt: Applications of Quasiconformal Geometry and Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Partial differential equations (PDE) are used to model important systems in various application areas; in particular, subelliptic PDE are helpful in settings where there is a constrained dynamics. Examples of such systems include the motion of robot arms, structural functions of the first layer of the mammalian visual cortex, the Black-Scholes model for financial markets, and quantum computing. Geometric and analytic properties of such spaces are captured in a quantitative fashion by studying the behavior of certain families of transformations of the space into itself. This project aims at studying fine properties of such transformations. In terms of broader impacts, the principal investigator will involve graduate and undergraduate students in several aspects of the research and will design outreach activities to attract K-12 students to mathematics.

The technical focus of the proposed research addresses a curve-shrinking flow in Carnot groups, the study of harmonic extensions of quasiconformal mappings between boundaries of certain Gromov hyperbolic spaces, and regularity of certain nonlinear, degenerate parabolic PDE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF THE SMITH COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Mathematics is a language through which humankind can experience reality, and describe it in a quantitative and qualitative way. 

A part of this language comes from Calculus, and allows to describe how a physical  system changes in time, and predict its future behavior. The study of these dynamics  and of the corresponding equilibrium stattes is the subject of the field called Partial Differential Equations (PDE). These evolutions depend closely from the geometric structure of the space where they take place.

The study of these dynamics is not well understood when the geometry of the ambient space is not smooth (like in a fractal).  Since these kind of non-smooth geometries arise often in modeling real world systems, it is important to develop the mathematics needed to study dynamics in them.

The focus of this project is to study the interaction between the non-smooth geometry of a space, and the behavior of solutions of Partial Differential Equationsin that space. 

The PI wrote 13 papers during this award, and lectured nationally and internationally about the research progress. The PI co-organized summer schools, and conferences where both junior and more senior researchers could interact. The PI has involved undergraduate and graduate students in their work.

The main results can be divided in the following categories:

- Study of curve shortening flows in subriemannian setting of Carnot groups

- Study of the regularity of solutions of quasilinear degenerate parabolic PDE in the model case of the Heisenberg group.

- Introduce a new way to define and study fractional operators in the context of metric measure spaces that satisfy a doubling property.

- Neural Networks algorithyms aimed at solving inverse problems in dynmical systems and in PDE.


Last Modified: 07/08/2024
Modified by: Luca Capogna
